definitions.title: Understanding Modal Verbs
definitions.definition: Modal verbs are special verbs that express ability, permission, necessity, or obligation.
definitions.example: Examples: can, can’t, must, mustn’t, have to, don’t have to
definitions.explanation: They show how certain, possible, or necessary an action is. For example, 'can' means able to, and 'must' means required.

definitions.title: Using 'Can' – Expressing Ability or Permission
definitions.definition: ‘Can’ is used to show that someone has the ability or is allowed to do something.
definitions.example: Example: 'You can join the online meeting if you want.'
definitions.explanation: It means you are able or permitted to do it. It’s positive and encouraging!

definitions.title: Using 'Can’t' – Expressing Impossibility or Prohibition
definitions.definition: ‘Can’t’ means you are not allowed to or not able to do something.
definitions.example: Example: 'You can’t go online yet; it’s not your turn.'
definitions.explanation: It tells someone that something is not possible or not permitted.

definitions.title: Using 'Must' – Expressing Strong Obligation or Necessity
definitions.definition: ‘Must’ shows that something is very important or required.
definitions.example: Example: 'Everyone must consult a doctor if they feel sick.'
definitions.explanation: It means the action is necessary — you have no choice but to do it.

definitions.title: Using 'Mustn’t' – Expressing Strong Prohibition
definitions.definition: ‘Mustn’t’ means something is not allowed or forbidden.
definitions.example: Example: 'You mustn’t visit restricted websites during class.'
definitions.explanation: It warns the listener that the action is not permitted and should be avoided.

definitions.title: Using 'Have To' – Expressing External Obligation
definitions.definition: ‘Have to’ shows that something is necessary because of rules or situations.
definitions.example: Example: 'You have to submit your project tomorrow.'
definitions.explanation: It’s used when the necessity comes from outside — like rules, teachers, or schedules.

definitions.title: Using 'Don’t Have To' – Expressing Lack of Necessity
definitions.definition: ‘Don’t have to’ means there is no need or obligation to do something.
definitions.example: Example: 'You don’t have to attend class today; it’s a holiday!'
definitions.explanation: It means it’s optional — you can do it, but it’s not required.

definitions.title: Using 'Should' – Expressing Advice or Expectation
definitions.definition: ‘Should’ is used to give advice or talk about what is right to do.
definitions.example: Example: 'You should study before the quiz tomorrow.'
definitions.explanation: It’s softer than ‘must’. It suggests the best or most responsible action.

definitions.title: Using 'Need To' – Expressing Requirement or Necessity
definitions.definition: ‘Need to’ means something is important and required to be done.
definitions.example: Example: 'We need to be quiet during the test.'
definitions.explanation: It shows that something is essential for success or respect of rules.

definitions.title: Using 'Can I' – Asking for Permission Politely
definitions.definition: ‘Can I’ is a polite way to ask if you are allowed to do something.
definitions.example: Example: 'Can I log in now, Mama? It’s almost class time.'
definitions.explanation: It’s a friendly way to ask for permission from someone in charge.
